title: How to Determine the Value of a Card in Star Wars: Card Trader

methods.name: Determining Values of Your Card Deck

steps.headline: Launch Star Wars: Card Trader.
steps.description: Locate the app on your device. The app icon has the Star Wars logo on it with some cards in the background. Tap on it.

steps.headline: Tap the cards icon on the rightmost part of the bottom toolbar.
steps.description: You will be brought to the screen with your current inventory of cards.

steps.headline: View the cards in My Cards.
steps.description: By default, the initial view will be My Cards. You can see this title at the header toolbar. Swipe up and down to see all your cards here.

steps.headline: Open a card.
steps.description: All your cards are beautifully organized and displayed in small portrait thumbnail views. Tap on the card you want to open. The card will be maximized on your screen so you can see it better. You are looking at the front side of the card.

steps.headline: View rear of the card.
steps.description: Tap on the card to flip it over so you can see the back side.

steps.headline: Check the card count.
steps.description: A good gauge for your card’s value is the card count. This is the number of cards available for the exact same card. The lower the number, the fewer cards there are, the rarer it is. A card with 1,000 count is rarer than a card with 5,000 count. Find this number on the lower right corner of the rear of the card.

methods.name: Determining Values of Cards During a Trade

steps.headline: Launch Star Wars Card Trader.
steps.description: Locate the app on your device. The app icon has the Star Wars logo on it with some cards in the background. Tap on it.

steps.headline: View pending trades.
steps.description: Tap the exchanging cards icon on the middle part of the bottom toolbar. You will be brought to the screen with your trades. Tap on the title on the header toolbar to see a drop-down list of filters. Tap “Pending Trades” from here, and all your open and active trades will be displayed, with the most recent ones at the top. Swipe down to see more trades.

steps.headline: View a trade.
steps.description: Each trade can be studied and analyzed based from the data provided. You can see your trade partner’s username, the current status of the trade, the cards being traded, and some action buttons at the bottom.

steps.headline: Open a card.
steps.description: The cards you’re getting from the trade are located on the left box, and the cards you’re giving are on the right box. Tap on a card to open it. The card will be maximized on your screen so you can see it better. You are looking at the front side of the card.

steps.headline: View rear of the card.
steps.description: Tap on the card to flip it over so you can see the back side.

steps.headline: Check card count.
steps.description: A good gauge for your card’s value is the card count. This is the number of cards available for the exact same card. The lower the number, the fewer cards there are, the rarer it is. A card with a 1,000 count is rarer than a card with 5,000 count. Find this number on the lower left corner of the rear of the card.

steps.headline: Assess the trade.
steps.description: By looking at the card counts of all the cards being traded, you can assess if the trade makes sense for you. You will be able to tell if you are being fair, under-trading, or over-trading. Do this every time you receive a trade proposal.

text: Determining Values of Your Card Deck Launch Star Wars: Card Trader. Locate the app on your device. The app icon has the Star Wars logo on it with some cards in the background. Tap on it. Tap the cards icon on the rightmost part of the bottom toolbar. You will be brought to the screen with your current inventory of cards. View the cards in My Cards. By default, the initial view will be My Cards. You can see this title at the header toolbar. Swipe up and down to see all your cards here. Open a card. All your cards are beautifully organized and displayed in small portrait thumbnail views. Tap on the card you want to open. The card will be maximized on your screen so you can see it better. You are looking at the front side of the card. View rear of the card. Tap on the card to flip it over so you can see the back side. Check the card count. A good gauge for your card’s value is the card count. This is the number of cards available for the exact same card. The lower the number, the fewer cards there are, the rarer it is. A card with 1,000 count is rarer than a card with 5,000 count. Find this number on the lower right corner of the rear of the card. Determining Values of Cards During a Trade Launch Star Wars Card Trader. Locate the app on your device. The app icon has the Star Wars logo on it with some cards in the background. Tap on it. View pending trades. Tap the exchanging cards icon on the middle part of the bottom toolbar. You will be brought to the screen with your trades. Tap on the title on the header toolbar to see a drop-down list of filters. Tap “Pending Trades” from here, and all your open and active trades will be displayed, with the most recent ones at the top. Swipe down to see more trades. View a trade. Each trade can be studied and analyzed based from the data provided. You can see your trade partner’s username, the current status of the trade, the cards being traded, and some action buttons at the bottom. Open a card. The cards you’re getting from the trade are located on the left box, and the cards you’re giving are on the right box. Tap on a card to open it. The card will be maximized on your screen so you can see it better. You are looking at the front side of the card. View rear of the card. Tap on the card to flip it over so you can see the back side. Check card count. A good gauge for your card’s value is the card count. This is the number of cards available for the exact same card. The lower the number, the fewer cards there are, the rarer it is. A card with a 1,000 count is rarer than a card with 5,000 count. Find this number on the lower left corner of the rear of the card. Assess the trade. By looking at the card counts of all the cards being traded, you can assess if the trade makes sense for you. You will be able to tell if you are being fair, under-trading, or over-trading. Do this every time you receive a trade proposal.
